person_358.name: Robert WilliamBrandling
person_358.description: The chief advocate for and publicist of George Stephenson’s safety lamp, campaigning to have Stephenson recognized, and rewarded, as the original inventor.

person_361.name: JohnBowes
person_361.description: 10th Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorne from 1776 (in the Scottish peerage). Owned several Durham collieries, and supported George Stephenson’s priority as inventor of the safety lamp.

person_369.name: ThomasLiddell
person_369.description: From 1821, 1st Baron Ravensworth. High Sheriff of Northumberland in 1804. He also employed George Stephenson from 1804 at his Killingworth colliery, and encouraged and financed him in the development of steam power.

person_320.name: GeorgeStephenson
person_320.description: Colliery and railway engineer in North East England. He and Davy conducted a virulent controversy over who had invented the miners' safety lamp. He also designed early railway locomatives.

person_417.name: Archimedes
person_417.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

person_263.name: Pluto
person_263.description: The ruler of the underworld in ancient Greek mythology and religion.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_130.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
person_130.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

person_304.name: DenisPapin
person_304.description: French-born assistant in the Royal Society of London. Developed an early form of the steam engine. FRSL.

person_611.name: JamesSmithson
person_611.description: Born Jacques-Louis Macie in Paris; became James Louis Macie upon naturalizing to Britain and in 1800 adopted his father's original surname of Smithson. Wealthy natural son of the Duke of Nothumberland. Proprietor of the Royal Institution who wrote on chemistry. Bequeathed his money to the United States to found the Smithsonian Institution. FRSL.

person_349.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
person_349.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

person_777.name: Giovan BattistaTessandori
person_777.description: Member of the Lucca Academy. Davy described his discoveries in evaporation experiments.

person_618.name: PeterElmsley
person_618.description: Classical scholar whom Davy commissioned to translate the texts from the Herculaneum papyri that Davy was unrolling at the end of the 1810s. FRSL.

person_275.name: Prometheus
person_275.description: In Greek mythology, defied the Olympian gods by stealing fire and giving it to humans.

person_780.name: Apelles
person_780.description: A renowned painter of ancient Greece. Pliny the Elder rated him superior to preceding and subsequent artists.

person_162.name: JohnPlayfair
person_162.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_508.name: Lucretius
person_508.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

person_102.name: Philalethes
person_102.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_638.name: JamesWard
person_638.description: Landscape and animal painter. Royal Academician.

place_1164.name: Sant'Agostino, Pesaro
place_1164.description: A Roman Catholic church located on Corso XI Settembre in the historic center of Pesaro, Italy.

place_728.name: Rimini
place_728.description: A city in north-eastern Italy located on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_1149.name: Caucasus Mountains
place_1149.description: A mountain range at the intersection of Asia and Europe

place_926.name: Sabina
place_926.description: Also called the Sabine Hills, a region in central Italy.

place_564.name: Foligno
place_564.description: Foligno is an ancient town of Italy in the province of Perugia in east central Umbria, on the Topino river.

place_561.name: Colfiorito
place_561.description: Colfiorito is a village in Umbria, central Italy.

place_565.name: Terni
place_565.description: Terni is a city in the southern portion of the region of Umbria in central Italy.

place_955.name: Rieti
place_955.description: A town and comune in Lazio, central Italy,

place_956.name: Rieti Valley
place_956.description: A small plain in central Italy, where lies the city of Rieti, Lazio. It is also known as Sacred Valley and Holy Valley.

place_929.name: Brescia
place_929.description: A city and comune in the region of Lombardy, in Italy.

place_551.name: Lago di Garda
place_551.description: Lake Garda is the largest lake in Italy.

place_726.name: Desenzano del Garda
place_726.description: A town in Lombardy located on the shore of Lake Garda.

place_848.name: Velino
place_848.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

place_196.name: Styria
place_196.description: Styria is a state in the south-east of Austria.

place_1151.name: Aterno-Pescara
place_1151.description: The Aterno-Pescara is a river system in Abruzzo, eastern central Italy. The river is known as the Aterno near its source in the mountains, but takes the name Pescara, actually a tributary, nearer the city of Pescara and the Adriatic Sea.

place_1386.name: River Farfa
place_1386.description: An Italian river which rises in the Sabine Hills in Lazio and flows into the Tiber. It is known for its deep gorges.

place_1152.name: Poggio San Lorenzo
place_1152.description: Poggio San Lorenzo is a comune in the Province of Rieti in the Italian region of Latium, located about 50 kilometres northeast of Rome and about 15 kilometres south of Rieti.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_931.name: Venice
place_931.description: The capital of northern Italy’s Veneto region, Venice is built on more than 100 small islands in a lagoon in the Adriatic Sea.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_1245.name: Lucignano
place_1245.description: municipality in the Province of Arezzo in the Italian region Tuscany

place_932.name: Serchio
place_932.description: The third longest river in the Italian region of Tuscany at 126 kilometres.

place_1246.name: Lima
place_1246.description: river in the Bagni di Lucca

place_615.name: Tiber River
place_615.description: The Tiber River is the third longest river in Italy. Rome is located on its banks.

place_577.name: Newcastle upon Tyne
place_577.description: Newcastle upon Tyne is a city in the north-east of England. It is located on the River Tyne's northern bank.

place_1204.name: Po Valley
place_1204.description: A vast plain area in Northern Italy, featuring the Po River.

place_542.name: Cagli
place_542.description: Cagli is a town and comune in the province of Pesaro e Urbino, Marche, central Italy.

place_543.name: Cantiano
place_543.description: Cantiano is a comune in the Province of Pesaro e Urbino in the Italian region Marche.

place_933.name: River Taro
place_933.description: A river in Emilia-Romagna, in northern Italy.

place_544.name: Fossombrone
place_544.description: Fossombrone is a town and comune in the province of Pesaro e Urbino, Marche, central Italy.

place_934.name: River Helicon
place_934.description: A former river in the Macedonian city Dion, mentioned in Greek mythology.

place_350.name: River Tweed
place_350.description: One of the greatest salmon rivers in the UK; it flows east across the Border region in Scotland and northern England.

place_220.name: Tyrrhenian Sea
place_220.description: The Tyrrhenian Sea is part of the Mediterranean Sea off the west coast of Italy.

place_547.name: Fano
place_547.description: Fano is a town and comune of the province of Pesaro and Urbino in the Marche region of Italy.

place_548.name: Clitunno River
place_548.description: The Clitunno is a river in Umbria, Italy.

place_549.name: Nocera Umbra
place_549.description: Nocera Umbra is a town and comune in the province of Perugia, Italy.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_178.name: Vatican City
place_178.description: The Vatican City is a city-state surrounded by Rome, Italy.

place_243.name: Carrara
place_243.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

place_546.name: Monte Testaccio
place_546.description: Monte Testaccio or Monte Testaceo, also known as Monte dei Cocci, is an artificial mound in Rome composed almost entirely of testae - fragments of broken ancient Roman pottery.

place_245.name: Ravenna
place_245.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_1029.name: Durham, England
place_1029.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

place_545.name: High Force
place_545.description: High Force is a waterfall on the River Tees, near Middleton-in-Teesdale, Teesdale, England.

place_1363.name: River Tees
place_1363.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

place_847.name: Cascata delle Marmore
place_847.description: A man-made waterfall created by the ancient Romans, located near Terni, Italy.

place_937.name: Lincolnshire
place_937.description: A ceremonial county in the East Midlands and Yorkshire and the Humber regions of England.

place_866.name: Nile
place_866.description: The Nile is the longest river in Africa.

place_419.name: Mount's Bay
place_419.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_513.name: Isles of Scilly
place_513.description: The Scilly Isles are an archipelago off the south western tip of Cornwall.

place_938.name: Guernsey
place_938.description: One of the Channel Islands in the English Channel near the French coast.

place_939.name: Jersey
place_939.description: The largest of the Channel Islands, between England and France.

place_940.name: Orkney
place_940.description: An archipelago off the northeastern coast of Scotland.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_180.name: Paestum
place_180.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_154.name: St. Peter's
place_154.description: St Peter's is a church built in the Renaissance style located in the Vatican City, west of the River Tiber.

place_708.name: Ischia
place_708.description: An island in the Gulf of Naples, Italy.

place_942.name: Bologna
place_942.description: A city in and the capital of the Emilia-Romagna region in Northern Italy, of which it is also its largest.

place_767.name: Bagni Caldi
place_767.description: A village in north-western Italy famous for its thermal baths.

place_1080.name: Florence
place_1080.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

place_947.name: Mantua
place_947.description: A city surrounded by 3 artificial lakes in the northern Italian region of Lombardy.

place_948.name: Ala
place_948.description: A comune in Trentino, north-eastern Italy.

place_952.name: Bagni di Lucca
place_952.description: A group of about 25 villages in northern Tuscany, less than 30 kilometres from Lucca, famous for its hot springs and thermal baths.

place_730.name: Milan
place_730.description: A city in northern Italy, and the capital of Lombardy.

place_949.name: Delphi
place_949.description: An ancient sacred precinct in Greece, the ancient Greeks considered the centre of the world to be in Delphi.

place_953.name: Lima River
place_953.description: Also Limia, runs west from the autonomous community of Galicia in Spain to Portugal.

place_321.name: Cheshire
place_321.description: A county in north-western England. The county town is Chester.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_260.name: Drava River
place_260.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_181.name: Carniola
place_181.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

place_328.name: Tyrol
place_328.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

place_329.name: Carinthia
place_329.description: Carinthia is the southernmost Austrian State.

place_770.name: Pisa
place_770.description: Pisa is a city in Italy's Tuscany region best known for its iconic Leaning Tower.

place_773.name: Province of Massa-Carrara
place_773.description: The province of Massa-Carrara is a province in the Tuscany region of central Italy.

place_562.name: Perugia
place_562.description: Perugia is the capital city of Umbria in central Italy, crossed by the River Tiber, and of the province of Perugia.

place_567.name: Arezzo
place_567.description: Arezzo is a city and comune in Italy and the capital of the province of the same name located in Tuscany.

otherwork_157.name: Quarterly Journal of Science and the Arts
otherwork_157.author: Sir Joseph Banks
